#Text=Chaves
#Text=Chaves is a beautiful city in Trás-os-Montes and one of the most historical cities in Portugal .
#Text=Chaves is a town and seat of municipality in the far North of Portugal , 10 km south of the Spanish border and 22 km south of Verín , Spain .
#Text=Is the second most populous of the district of Vila Real .
#Text=The district capital , Vila Real , is 60 km south on the A24 toll-free motorway .
#Text=Aquæ Flaviæ was the Roman name for this town .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Chaves is surrounded by mountains and that brings windy and changing weather , so you 'd better bring a jacket or an umbrella with you , at least in and autumn and winter .
#Text=By plane
#Text=The easy way to go to Chaves by plane is going to Oporto airport , and then catch a Bus or highway to Chaves .
#Text=It takes about one hour and half from Oporto .
#Text=There are low cost companies flying to Porto Oporto , one of them is Ryanair .
#Text=By train
#Text=There is no train service .
#Text=By boat
#Text=River Tamega .
#Text=See
#Text=The Pedestrian Bridge and the Riverside Green Area
#Text=On November 15
#Text=an extensive green area on the east side of the Tâmega River between the Engenheiro Carmona Bridge and the Public Gardens was opened to the public .
#Text=It has a playground , pedestrian and cycling paths , and a large grassy area .
#Text=An ultra-modern pedestrian bridge will soon be open linking the park of the hot springs and this new recreational area .
#Text=At the same time a cycling and walking path has been built on both banks of the river extending north for several kilometers .
#Text=Forte São Francisco
#Text=Strongly protected by the defence of the border with Galicia , by the Middle Ages the medieval town of Chaves , became unprotected .
#Text=It had to fortify itself , garrison the nearby hilltops , in order to keep them from being occupied by enemy artillery .
#Text=The first to be considered was the hill of Pedisqueira , where there was a Franciscan convent .
#Text=Decided during the final phase of the Portuguese Restoration War ( 1640-1668 ) , to build a fort according to the modern concepts of military engineering .
#Text=This fort played an important role in the Napoleonic invasion of Portugal in 1807 when it was captured by Marshall Soult and then retaken when a light garrison was left to guard it .
#Text=It was also the scene of several pro-royalist revolts in the early eighteenth century and later in 1910 .
#Text=The fort is standing in a reasonable state of preservation .

#Text=The recent acquisition of the site by a hotel group directed by Comendador António Ramos and the construction of a four-star hotel using the old buildings has given new life to a ruined monument .
#Text=The fort is based on the Vauban system , with a four-pointed star , each one serving as a lookout tower .
#Text=The walls are all of granite , with about one meter of thickness .
#Text=The height varies according to the slope of the terrain , but the maximum point has 20 m.
#Text=The main entrance faces the south , with a drawbridge over the moat that no longer exists .
#Text=There are other gates , to the east and west .
#Text=To go inside we follow a tunnel that leads to the center of the fort .

#Text=Inside , besides the old church of São Francisco , where for three centuries lay the sarcophagus of the first Duke of Bragança , there are other buildings which have been artistically converted into hotel rooms .
#Text=These had served the army as barracks for many years , and later were used to lodge families that had returned from the Portuguese colonies when these got their independence in the 1970s .
#Text=A visit to the fort is well worth it , if not to stay in the hotel , but only to walk around the outside walls and contemplate the impressive view of Chaves .
#Text=Do
#Text=Watch football ie soccer at GD Chaves , who play in Primeira Liga , the top tier of Portuguese football .
#Text=Their home ground is Estádio Municipal de Chaves ( capacity 8000 ) , 1 km north of town centre .
#Text=There is a brand new casino .
#Text=Go next
#Text=Vidago , Pedras Salgadas , Bragança .
